2016
<math alttext="dollar sign 99.3"><semantics><mrow><mo>$</mo><mn>99.3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>
2017
<math alttext="dollar sign 97.7"><semantics><mrow><mo>$</mo><mn>97.7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/vnd.wiris.mtweb-params+json">{"digitSeparatorsAsMN":"auto"}</annotation></semantics></math>

​The table gives amounts of United States federal education spending, in billions of dollars, for selected years. A linear regression is used to construct a function model <math alttext="S"><mi>S</mi></math> that models the spending, in billions of dollars, over the given years. If <math alttext="t equals 1"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> corresponds to 2011, <math alttext="t equals 2"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> corresponds to 2012, and this pattern continues, which of the following defines function <math alttext="S"><mi>S</mi></math> ?

choices.label: ​<math alttext="S open parentheses t close parentheses equals negative 2.55 t plus 114.157"><mi>S</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2.55</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>114.157</mn></math>

​<math alttext="S open parentheses t close parentheses equals negative 2.55 t plus 5239.657"><mi>S</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2.55</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5239.657</mn></math>

​<math alttext="S open parentheses t close parentheses equals negative 8.099 t plus 113.820"><mi>S</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>8.099</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>113.820</mn></math>

​<math alttext="S open parentheses t close parentheses equals negative 0.369 t plus 42.308"><mi>S</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>0.369</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>42.308</mn></math>

content.answer: ​<math alttext="S open parentheses t close parentheses equals negative 2.55 t plus 114.157"><mi>S</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2.55</mn><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>114.157</mn></math>

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Construct new functions, using transformations, compositions, inverses, or regressions, that may be useful in modeling contexts, criteria, or data, with and without technology.
